poem:
**Collision Over the Potomac**

Night splits open,  
a violent ribbon—  
metal meets sky,  
sky meets water—  
a scatter of stars  
and bodies find  
their quiet depths;  
overhead echoes  
linger in ripples;  
on the banks,  
a mourning,  
a whispered prayer—  
and the river holds  
each breathless  
story close.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Rescuers search Washington DC river after plane collides with military helicopter Rescuers scouring the Potomac River in Washington DC after an American Airlines jet carrying 64 people collided with a US army Black Hawk helicopter on approach to Reagan national airport on Wednesday night have recovered 27 bodies from the water and believe no one survived the crash. The midair collision occurred at about 9pm on Wednesday when American Airlines flight 5342 – a regional". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
